<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_io_block_set:
```c
int metal_io_block_set(struct metal_io_region *io, unsigned long offset,
	       unsigned char value, int len)
{
	unsigned char *ptr = metal_io_virt(io, offset);
	int retlen = len;

	if (!ptr)
		return -ERANGE;
	if ((offset + len) > io->size)
		len = io->size - offset;
	retlen = len;
	if (io->ops.block_set) {
		(*io->ops.block_set)(
			io, offset, value, memory_order_seq_cst, len);
	} else {
		unsigned int cint = value;
		unsigned int i;

		for (i = 1; i < sizeof(int); i++)
			cint |= ((unsigned int)value << (CHAR_BIT * i));

		for (; len && ((uintptr_t)ptr % sizeof(int)); ptr++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)ptr = (unsigned char) value;
		for (; len >= (int)sizeof(int); ptr += sizeof(int),
						len -= sizeof(int))
			*(unsigned int *)ptr = cint;
		for (; len != 0; ptr++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)ptr = (unsigned char) value;
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_seq_cst);
	}
	return retlen;
}
```

suspicious_frags:
for (; len && ((uintptr_t)ptr % sizeof(int)); ptr++, len--)

for (; len != 0; ptr++, len--)

explanation: The earlier for loop "for (i = 1; i < sizeof(int); i++) ..." appears to be a single-counter loop where the first clause initializes the counter, the second clause has no persistent side effects, and the third clause increments only the loop counter — it therefore does not need investigation for Rule 14.2. Other code (pointer checks, ops.block_set call, variable initializations, atomic_thread_fence) do not form for statements and are not relevant to the well-formedness requirements of Rule 14.2. The three flagged for statements use multiple objects in the loop control (len and ptr), and their third clauses modify more than one object (ptr and len), or their second clauses reference objects that are modified in the loop body; these are the fragments that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2.
